repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
text-decoration: none;

Underline on _hover_ is probably a good idea though. (i.e. don't do `text-decoration: none;` for `:hover` or `:focus`)
Wouldn't it be nice to have some other visual indication that it's clickable then, besides cursor turning into pointer on hover? That's the only reason I didn't add that.

I think that makes actual links less meaningful. There are many of these too. And most of them go "nowhere" (except the current page). So it's very noisy to decorate them as clickable things.

People who want to get the anchor will naturally hover over the heading to try that. That's a common pattern.
Makes sense. Added that as well as a TODO comment
Didn't see a comment edit initially. Changed rule to only remove underline if link is not hovered.
I don't think it's needed for `:focus` though, because browsers have a separate outline when navigating with a keyboard.

comment_regular_data.body:
I noticed this CSS rule, which I believe would only make sense if help tags would be output as `a`, but as I see they're only output as either `code` or `span`. Should it be deleted then?

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/6b5f44817e93c2985f3ea32122f1dc0047054018/scripts/gen_help_html.lua#L966-L969
Not sure if this change should be mentioned in "news.txt" or commit message should be changed instead

Doesn't need a news entry (not about Neovim itself).

Also, duplicate of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24989 (which didn't wait for justin to get back)?

>Doesn't need a news entry (not about Neovim itself).

Should I change commit message to `build: ...` or `docs: ...` then?

>Also, duplicate of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24989 (which didn't wait for justin to get back)?

Yes, I saw that PR before, that's why I didn't submit earlier, but unfortunately now even branch is deleted.
I think you can just ignore the failing news.txt check

> Should I change commit message to build: ... or docs: ... then?

It's fine; the check is not required, it's just a reminder. (Sorry, can't unhide comments for some reason.)

> Yes, I saw that PR before, that's why I didn't submit earlier, but unfortunately now even branch is deleted.

Yes, unfortunately. I just wanted to bring this up so they at least got a shout-out. Your PR is a bit more extensive, but if you included any changes from the old PR (deliberately or not), you could consider adding them as a `Co-authored by: ` in the commit message.

> Yes, unfortunately. I just wanted to bring this up so they at least got a shout-out. Your PR is a bit more extensive, but if you included any changes from the old PR (deliberately or not), you could consider adding them as a `Co-authored by: ` in the commit message.

Actually I just searched for "id=" in that file to determine where the changes should be. I remember that the changes in another PR were somewhere around those lines as well, which couldn't be otherwise I guess. I can't see the diff anymore though. But I don't see any problem adding "Co-authored by: " line in commit message anyway as well.
I don't see author name or email as well there. So I put github username in there. Is that acceptable?
It's your decision; anything is fine with me.
Thank you! Let me test locally for a bit

This adds underlines to all the anchors now, e.g. `vim.builtin`, `vim.api` right-side of the screenshot: - That seems noisy because these links don't actually go anywhere. We want them to be clickable but we don't want them to "invite" clicks, because that makes _actual links_ less meaningful.

> I noticed this CSS rule, which I believe would only make sense if help tags would be output as a, but as I see they're only output as either code or span. Should it be deleted then?

Thanks for noticing that. Will take a closer look later. Maybe add a comment like `TODO: delete this? help tags are rendered as <code> or <span>, not <a>`.

title: feat(gen_help_html): add anchors to help tags
